WRITING.TITLE: [Differential Equation] What is wrong with the solution? I try to find the Inverse Laplace Transform of a convolutive type integral, yet the answer is different compare to book which is 1 + (1/2)t^2. My solution was provided on the picture below. Any help is appreciated. Thank You, Reddit.

WRITING.TEXT: Let u = #8730;x and v = (2 #8730;x - 1) f(x) = u/v The function is intended to be solved using quotient rule, but you can manipulate the variable 'v' if you want to solve it using product rule. Since 1/v = v^(-1) then f(x) = u #215; v^(-1) You can solve the v^(-1) using chain rule the proceed to product rule. You can solve the function using either product rule or quotient rule, but it is more tedious to use a product rule because you will need to use the chain rule before using the product rule itself.

You can use this guide from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology which discuss how to properly construct a clear outline of your mathematical research paper. (https://www.researchgate.net/publication/248477911_Writing_a_Math_Phase_Two_Paper)
The cos(2x) was not distributed. The integral was solve using u substitution where u = sin(2x) and du = 2cos(2x) dx. The du will replace the cos(2x) dx of the integral.
volume = width #215; length #215; height

However, if the experiment requires a high purity hydrochloric acid for precise and accurate results, analytical grade should be use.

WRITING.TITLE: [Question] How to solve the coordinate of a point using the distance formula?
WRITING.TEXT: I have this mathematical problem where the value of coordinate of another point and the angle of the line with respect to x axis is not given, only the length of the line is given. I try to solve the problem using distance formula. For example: d = 9 x_1, y_1 = (0, 0) x_2, y_2 = (x_2, y_2) d = #8730;(x_2 - x_1)^2 + (y_2 - y_1)^2 9 = #8730;(x_2 - 0)^2 + (y_2 - 0)^2 9 = #8730;(x_2 )^2 + (y_2)^2 81 = (x_2 )^2 + (y_2)^2 The equation is an equation of a circle. 81 = (x_2 )^2 + (y_2)^2 r^2 = x^2 + y^2 where r = 9 Conversion of polar to rectangular: x = 9cos( #952;) y = 9sin( #952;) cos( #952;) = x/9 sin( #952;) = y/9 #952; = cos^-1 (x/9) #952; = sin^-1 (y/9) However, I was not able to solve this part because the angle is not given. Any help is highly appreciated. Thank You, Reddit.

The ionic product constant is a product of H^+ and OH^- , while the acid or base dissociation constant is a ratio of the equilibrium constants.

SN1 AND SN2 REACTIONS OF HALOALKANES 1. If the type of haloalkane is methyl then SN1 will not occur since the methyl cation is unstable; SN2 is favored on this type of haloalkane. 2. If the type of haloalkane is primary then SN1 will not occur since the primary carbocations are unstable; SN2 is favored on this type of haloalkane. 3. If the type of haloalkane is secondary then both the substitution reactions are will occur. SN1 will occur in protic solvents with poor nucleophiles, while SN2 will occur in aprotic solvents with good nucleophiles. 4. If the type of haloalkane is tertiary then SN2 will not occur because of the steric hindrance around the substitution center; SN1 will occur due to the ease of formation of tertiary carbocations. E1 AND E2 REACTIONS OF HALOALKANES 1. If the type of haloalkane is primary then E1 will not occur since the primary carbocations are unstable, E2 is favored on this type of haloalkane. 2. If the type of haloalkane is secondary then both elimination reactions will occur. If the reaction has weak bases such as H2O and ROH then E1 will occur; if the reaction had strong bases such as OH^- and OR^- then E2 will occur. 2. If the type of haloalkane is tertiary then both elimination reactions will occur. If the reaction has weak bases such as H2O and ROH then E1 will occur; if the reaction had strong bases such as OH^- and OR^- then E2 will occur.

[Question] How does non-acidic Vitamin C is being prepared?

WRITING.TEXT: In cases where a visual indicator is unavailable, potentiometric indication of the end point can often be used. Potentiometric titrations are among the most accurate known because the potential follows the actual change in activity and, therefore, the end point will often coincide directly with the equivalence point. Potentiometric titrations are straightforward. They involve measurement of an indicating electrode potential against a convenient reference electrode and plotting the change of this potential difference against volume of titrant. The indicating electrode in precipitation titrations is used to follow the change in pM or pA, where M is the cation of the precipitate and A is the anion. A glass pH electrode is used to follow acid-base titrations, silver electrode is used to follow titrations with silver ion, and inert electrode (platinum) is used to follow redox titrations. Reference: Christian, G. D., Dasgupta, P. K., amp; Schug, K. A. (2014). Analytical Chemistry (7th Ed.). Wiley.
